questions.text: Preferred medical treatment for preoperative shrinkage of somatotrope adenoma leading to large spade like hands and impaired glucose tolerance is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Lanreotide 

Explanation:

The preferred medical treatments for patients with acromegaly include long-acting injectable SRL depot formulations of octreotide and lanreotide as well as oral octreotide capsules.

Incorrect options 

Cabergoline in high dose has adjunctive effect but not first line drug. Pegvisomant antagonizes endogenous GH action by blocking peripheral GH binding to its receptor. Consequently, serum IGF-1 levels are suppressed, reducing the deleterious effects of excess endogenous GH.

questions.text: Best test to confirm the diagnosis of acromegaly is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C: Glucose challenge test ( 75 grams )

Explanation:

Diagnosis of acromegaly is confirmed by demonstrating failure of GH suppression to <0.4 μg/L within 1–2 h of an oral glucose load (75 g)

Incorrect options 

IGF-1 level is a screening test for acromegaly. IGF-2 plays a role in prenatal growth and not postnatal. MRI pituiatry will only tell about mass in pituitary but cannot tell which hormone is being produced in excess or is deficient.

questions.text: Prolactin levels can be increased in all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Secondary hypothyroidism

Acromegaly can arise from Mammosomatotrope cell adenoma leading to excess GH as well as prolactin 

TRH stimulates the anterior pituitary to release TSH and prolactin. In primary hypothyroidism, T4 and T3 are low causing rise of TRH. This increased TRH will cause both TSH and prolactin to rise contributing to galactorrhea.

Secodary hypothyroidism has pituitary damage leading to low TSH and low prolactin

Prolactinoma will cause excess prolactin leading to galactorrhea and menstural abnormalities

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with spade like hands, coarse facies and increased spacing between his lower teeth. Which of the following is screening test for this case?

choices.text: GH levels after 2 hour of glucose challenge test

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: IGF-1 levels 

Patient is having acromegaly. Screening test is IGF-1 levels and best to confirm the diagnosis is failure to suppress GH Levels to <  0.4 ug/L 

Owing to the pulsatility of GH secretion, measurement of a single random GH level is not useful for the diagnosis or exclusion of acromegaly

questions.text: 50-year-old woman presents with increase in size of hand and feet with voice changes and carpal tunnel syndrome. IGF -1 levels are increased. Which of the following findings will likely not be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is Option A: Hypoglycemic attacks 

GH is counter regulatory hormone causing increase of blood glucose and impaired glucose tolerance in patients with acromegaly. 

Presence of Mammosomatotrope cell adenoma can explain galactorrhea 

Pituitary adenoma > 10 mm can press on optic chiasma leading to bitemporal hemianopia 

Acromegaly is associated with increased risk of colonic polyps and mortality from colonic malignancy

questions.text: 45-year-old man presents with headaches, frequent change in shoe size and visual field defects. MRI head is shown below. IGF-1 is elevated and GH levels remain elevated on glucose challenge. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Perform transsphenoidal surgical resection

The clinical signs of enlargement of feet, visual field defects likely from optic chiasma compression and biochemical evidence of excess of GH points to acromegaly. MRI head shows somatotroph pituitary macroadenoma with mass effect. Transsphenoidal surgical resection is the preferred treatment.

 

Management of Acromegaly

Surgical Treatment

Transsphenoidal surgical resection is the preferred treatment, especially for those with GH-secreting adenomas.

 

Post-Surgery:

  • Improvement in soft tissue swelling and normalization of GH levels typically occur shortly after surgery
  • IGF-1 levels normalize within 3-4 days.
  • There is a 10% recurrence rate of acromegaly years later, and up to 15% of patients may develop hypopituitarism.

Medical therapy

Preferred in medical therapy if curative surgery is not feasible or if GH fails to decrease post resection

  • Somatostatin Receptor Ligands (SRLs): (Option B ruled out)
    • Long-acting injectable forms (octreotide, lanreotide).
    • Normalizes GH and IGF-1 levels in about 50% of patients.
    • Side Effects: GI disturbances, transient nausea, and gallbladder issues.
  • GH receptor antagonist:
    • Pegvisomant blocks peripheral GH receptors, normalizing IGF-1 levels in about 70% of patients, though GH levels remain elevated. It is administered through daily subcutaneous injections and is used for recurrences or poor responses to SRLs.
  • Dopamine Agonists: (Option A ruled out)
    • High doses of cabergoline can provide modest GH suppression.

Radiation Therapy (Option D ruled out)

External beam radiation therapy or stereotactic techniques are considered for patients not achieving biochemical control through surgery or medical therapy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman experiences severe postpartum hemorrhage during delivery, requiring a blood transfusion. Two weeks later, she reports fatigue, weight loss and failure of lactation.  Which of the following hormone replacement will not be required in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Melatonin 

The clinical presentation, along with a history of PPH during delivery, suggests sheehan syndrome. It refers to acute infarction and ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland due to postpartum hemorrhage and subsequent hypovolemic hypotension.

Melatonin is released from pineal gland and regulates circadian rhythm /sleep–wake cycle and does not need replacement in sheehan syndrome 

Lifelong hormone replacement is of 

1. Glucocorticoids (Hydrocortisone / Prednisone) → always replace first to avoid adrenal crisis.

2. Levothyroxine (for secondary hypothyroidism)

3. Estrogen ± Progesterone (for women not desiring fertility) Or GnRH/gonadotropins if fertility desired.

4. Growth Hormone/ Somatotropin replacement may be considered in selected adults with hypopituitarism to improve metabolic function and quality of life, but is not required in all cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for a patient with Sheehan syndrome?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation, along with a history of PPH during delivery & low cortisol & thyroid hormone levels, suggests Sheehan Syndrome.
  • The initial management for a patient with suspected Sheehan syndrome, particularly with evidence of adrenal insufficiency, is to start hydrocortisone to replace cortisol.

 

Sheehan syndrome

Investigations

Brain MRI/CECT

  • A secondary partial or complete empty sella

(Primary empty sella syndrome, or arachnoidocele, is a radiologic finding where the sella turcica appears empty due to CSF herniation from the subarachnoid space, compressing and flattening the pituitary gland within it.).

  • Serum findings
    • Growth hormone, Prolactin, ACTH, TSH, LH and FSH ↓.
    • ADH is normal as the posterior pituitary is typically not affected.

Management

Hormone Replacement Therapies:

  • Cortisol Replacement:
    • Administer hydrocortisone (Initial treatment) if there is ACTH deficiency.
    • Mineralocorticoid is not typically recommended. (Option C)
 
  • Thyroid Hormone Replacement:
    • Indication: Levothyroxine (50–150 μg) should be given once daily.
    • Aim to maintain serum T4 in the upper range of normal.
    • Thyroid hormone (Option A) should not be administered without glucocorticoid therapy in cases of adrenal insufficiency, as this can lead to an adrenal crisis.
 
  • Sex Hormone Replacement: Recommended for women under 50 years with gonadotropin deficiency and for men to restore sexual function and prevent osteoporosis.
 
  • Growth Hormone Replacement:
    • Growth hormone (GH) is given via daily subcutaneous injections for children and adolescents with GH deficiency (Option D)
    • Side Effects: The primary side effect is sodium retention, which may present as peripheral oedema or carpal tunnel syndrome
    • GH replacement should start at a low dose, with regular monitoring of serum IGF-1 to assess response.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of irregular menstrual cycles, galactorrhea, and difficulty conceiving. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum prolactin levels. MRI of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements about the given condition is not true?

choices.text: Female-to-Male ratio is approximately 20:1 for microadenomas
Men generally present with symptoms earlier than women
Prolactin levels correlate with the size of the tumor

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with elevated prolactin levels & MRI showing a mass in the sellar region suggests Prolactinoma, where men often present later with larger tumours due to less obvious signs of hormonal imbalance.

 

Prolactinoma: (M/C functioning pituitary tumor)

  • Prolactinomas are typically microadenomas in pre-menopausal women, as the symptoms of elevated prolactin levels often lead to early diagnosis.
  • Prolactin levels correlate with the size of the tumour (Option D ruled out)
  • Dopamine inhibits the production of prolactin.

Classification of Tumors:

  • Microadenomas: Tumors < 1 cm in diameter.
  • Macroadenomas: Tumors greater than 1 cm in diameter & can be locally invasive and compress adjacent structures such as Optic Chaisma, resulting inBitemporal Hemianopia) (Option C ruled out)
    • Female-to-male ratio for micro prolactinomas is approximately 20:1 (Option A ruled out)
    • For macroadenomas, the ratio is close to 1:1.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Prolactin has inhibitory effects on FSH & LH.
  • Women: Commonly present with amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhea. If the tumour extends beyond the sella, visual field defects & mass effects occur.
  • Men: Typically present with impotence, loss of libido, infertility, or signs of central nervous system (CNS) compression, such as headaches and visual disturbances.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with erectile dysfunction and galactorrhea. Blood tests confirm elevated prolactin levels and an MRI reveals a macroadenoma. Which of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Start cabergoline

For patients with macroadenomas and significant symptoms, initiation of dopamine agonist therapy (such as cabergoline or bromocriptine) is the first-line treatment to reduce prolactin levels and shrink the tumor. Lanreotide is used to shrink GH producing adenoma in case of acromegaly. 

Diagnosis of Prolactinoma:

  • PRL levels > 200 μg/L most likely indicates prolactinoma
  • PRL levels below 100 μg/L may indicate microadenomas
  • MRI Head is recommended for all patients with hyperprolactinemia
    • Shows suprasellar mass.

Management:

  • Asymptomatic microadenomas: No treatment if fertility is not desired. Regular monitoring and imaging are recommended. 
  • Symptomatic microadenomas: Use dopamine agonists, titrated for optimal PRL suppression. Normal PRL levels do not guarantee tumor shrinkage.
  • Macroadenomas: Perform visual field testing before starting dopamine agonists. Follow-up with MRI and visual field assessments every 6-12 months.

questions.text: A 32 year old nulliparous woman comes to the OB-GYN department for investigation of infertility. She also complains of occasional headaches and galactorrhoea. Lab tests and imaging lead to a diagnosis of prolactinoma. If we want to restore fertility in this patient, which of the following is the treatment of choice in this patient?

choices.text: Cabergoline therapy till pregnancy is confirmed
Bromocriptine therapy till pregnancy is confirmed
Radiotherapy for mass reduction of tumor

questions.solution:
In order to restore fertility in this patient, Bromocriptine therapy can be used until pregnancy is confirmed

 

Treatment of prolactinoma in pregnancy

Desire for fertility

DOC - Bromocriptine

  • Bromocriptine therapy is initiated to restore fertility
  • It is short-acting and has low teratogenic effects
  • Mechanical contraception should be practiced for the first 3 menstrual cycles after initiation of therapy to allow for conception timing
  • After pregnancy is confirmed - the drug is discontinued, and serial monitoring of prolactin levels
  • Drug may be reintroduced if tumor growth is apparent

Visual field defect

If the tumor is very large and threatens the vision, surgical decompression may be done

 

Cabergoline therapy (Option A), although it is the first line therapy for prolactinoma, is not preferred in those patients desiring fertility because it is long acting as it has a high affinity for D2-receptors.

 

Radiotherapy for mass reduction of tumor (Option C) is reserved for aggressive tumors that do not respond to dopamine agonists or surgery; thus, it is not recommended for this patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the stalk effect of the pituitary?

choices.text: Hyperprolactinemia occurs due to a hypersecreting macroadenoma
There is reduced secretion of dopamine in the pituitary stalk
Significant deficiencies in other pituitary hormones are not present
Prolactin level is usually less than 200 ng/ml

questions.solution:
Hyperprolactinemia in the stalk effect occurs due to compression of the pituitary stalk by a non-secreting pituitary macroadenoma and not due to a hypersecreting macroadenoma.

  • Compression of the pituitary stalk results in decreased secretion of dopamine in the pituitary stalk, which leads to unopposed prolactin secretion (Option B ruled out)
  • A serum prolactin level below 200 ng/mL can be observed in cases with a "stalk effect". Serum prolactin level above 200 ng/mL typically indicates a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma. (Option D ruled out)
  • There is no significant deficiency in other pituitary hormones (Option C ruled out)
  • Thus, the hormonal profile in the stalk effect
    • GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH normal or ↓
    • Prolactin ↑ but less than 200 ng/mL

questions.text:
Match the following pituitary gland disorders with their respective serum hormone levels.

 


	
		
			
			Pituitary gland disorder 
			
			
			Serum hormone levels 
			
		
		
			
			1. Hypopituitarism
			
			
			a) Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones maybe ↓ or normal
			
		
		
			
			2. Sheehan syndrome
			
			
			b) GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin, ADH ↓
			
		
		
			
			3. Pituitary apoplexy
			
			
			c) GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH normal or ↓; prolactin ↑
			
		
		
			
			4. Stalk effect
			
			
			d) GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin ↓ and ADH normal
questions.solution:
Pituitary hormone levels in different pituitary gland disorders

Hypopituitarism

It occurs due to damage in the pituitary gland caused by tumors, surgery, trauma, or genetic conditions.

GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin, ADH ↓ (deficiency varies based on which cells are affected).

Sheehan syndrome

Postpartum hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe blood loss during childbirth.

GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, prolactin ↓ and ADH normal

Pituitary apoplexy

A medical emergency involving sudden hemorrhage or infarction in the pituitary gland.

Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones may be ↓ or normal

Stalk effect

Compression or disruption of the pituitary stalk causing a reduction in hypothalamic inhibition of prolactin, resulting in elevated prolactin levels without other pituitary hormone abnormalities.

GH, ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH normal or ↓, prolactin ↑

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of pituitary adenoma presents with sudden-onset severe headache, palpitations, excessive sweating, and hypotension. Lab results show severe hypoglycemia, and imaging reveals hemorrhage within the pituitary and deviation of the pituitary stalk. What is the initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Considering this patient’s history of pituitary adenoma and his current clinical presentation, he has most likely developed pituitary apoplexy.
High-dose IV glucocorticoids are the first-line treatment that addresses adrenal insufficiency, stabilizes blood pressure, and corrects hypoglycemia.

 

Pituitary apoplexy

Pathology

  • Acute intra-pituitary hemorrhage resulting in an endocrine emergency
  • It may arise spontaneously in preexisting adenomas, occur postpartum or be associated with conditions like diabetes, hypertension, sickle cell anemia, or acute shock.
  • Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones maybe ↓ or normal

Clinical features

  • Severe headache
  • Central nervous system (CNS) hemorrhage
  • Signs of meningeal irritation
  • Loss of consciousness
  • Bilateral visual changes
  • Ophthalmoplegia (eye muscle paralysis)
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypotension
  • Shock
  • Cardiovascular collapse

Management

  • High-dose glucocorticoids is the first line of treatment to correct adrenal insufficiency, stabilize blood pressure, and correct hypoglycemia.
  • Patients without evident visual loss or impaired consciousness can be managed conservatively with high-dose glucocorticoids.
  • Urgent surgical decompression: Required for patients with significant or progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness.
  • Monitoring: Visual recovery is inversely correlated with the duration of time after the acute event, so timely intervention is crucial.

 

Urgent surgical decompression (Option A) is not indicated in this patient as he does not have any signs of visual defects, cranial nerve palsy or impaired consciousness. Thus, he can be treated conservatively with medical therapy.

 

IV dextrose administration (Option C) can temporarily address hypoglycemia but it does not address the underlying adrenal insufficiency which is a medical emergency. Glucocorticoids are needed to stabilize adrenal function, after which glucose levels will normalize.

 

Oral hydrocortisone (Option D) is not preferred as this is an acute endocrine emergency, and oral corticosteroids are not fast acting thus only IV forms of corticosteroid are preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is mismatched with its hormonal profile and management

choices.text:
Lymphocytic hypophysitis - variable deficiency in pituitary hormone

Sheehan syndrome - treated with hormone replacement therapy

Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary - ADH deficiency present

Lymphocytic hypophysitis - Glucocorticoid to reduce inflammation

Sheehan syndrome - Panhypopituitarism

Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary - surgical excision of the lesion

Lymphocytic hypophysitis - Glucocorticoid to reduce inflammation

Sheehan syndrome - ADH deficiency present

Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary-thyroid hormone replacement is essential.

Lymphocytic hypophysitis - Surgical excision if vision is affected

Sheehan syndrome - Thyroid hormone replacement after Corticosteroids are stabilized

Langerhans cell histiocytosis of pituitary - Chemotherapy is systemic involvement present

questions.solution:
Features

Sheehan syndrome

Lymphocytic hypophysitis

LCH of pituitary

Cause

Occurs due to postpartum ischemic necrosis of the pituitary, commonly presenting with panhypopituitarism

An autoimmune inflammation of the pituitary, causing variable hormone deficiencies

Infiltration of the pituitary by Langerhans cells

Hormone profile

Panhypopituitarism, except for ADH

Variable deficiencies: often low ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, PRL,

ADH deficiency presenting as central diabetes insipidus

 

May have low or normal pituitary hormones depending on the degree of infiltration

Treatment

Hormone replacement

  • Glucocorticoid replacement to manage adrenal insufficiency.
  • Thyroid hormone replacement after corticosteroids are stabilized.
  • Gonadal hormone replacement

Corticosteroids to manage inflammation

 

Hormone replacement as needed for any deficiencies.

 

Surgery only if visual field compromise or other complications arise.

Surgical resection of affected mass

 

Chemotherapy may be needed if systemic involvement present

  • Vinblastine
  • Methotrexate-containing regimens
  • Cytarabine

questions.text: Which of the following is the sequence of hormonal supplementation in a patient of Panhypopituitarism

choices.text: Glucocorticoids → Thyroid hormones → Growth hormone → Sex hormones
Glucocorticoid → thyroid hormone → Sex hormones → Growth hormone
Thyroid hormones → Sex hormones → Glucocorticoids → Growth hormone
Sex hormones → Growth hormone → Glucocorticoids → Thyroid hormones

questions.solution:
For panhypopituitarism, the sequence of hormone replacement therapy is Glucocorticoid → thyroid hormone → Sex hormones → Growth hormone

 

Hormonal therapy for Panhypopituitarism

Hormone deficient

Hormone replacement

ACTH

Corticosteroid replacement should be started first to reduce the risk of triggering an adrenal crisis.

  • Hydrocortisone 10-20 mg/day in divided doses
  • Cortisone acetate 15-25 mg/day in divided doses
  • Prednisolone 5 mg/day

TSH

Thyroid hormone replacement is then added for hypothyroidism

  • L-thyroxine 0.0075 - 0.15 mg/day

FSH/LH

After thyroid hormone replacement - sex hormone replacement is initiated

  • Males - testosterone
  • Females - estrogen / progesterone / gonadotropins

GH
  • Adults - Somatotropin (0.1 - 1.25 mg SC QID)
  • Children - Somatotropin (0.02 - 0.05 mg/kg/day)

Vasopressin

  • Intranasal desmopressin (5–20 g BID/day)
  • Oral 300–600 μg QID
